speaker: Mr Edwards (Cowan) (5.57 P.m.)
theText: While the opposition support the Assistance forTuesday, 23 March 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 4127 the community and have a look at some of those real problems and some of the people that are carrying the burden of this government's neglect in this area. I want to speak about a different aspect from those raised by others. I want to refer to parts 2, 3 and 4 of schedule 1, which makes some minor technical amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. In my view, these amendments do not go far enough, and I will go through them and explain why I am saying that. I have been approached by a person who provides some financial support to a person who is a quadriplegic. In approaching me, this person has outlined to me how this particular client-and I will give his name: it is a Mr Dario Sinibaldi-requires care around the clock. In 1991 he was awarded a lump sum to pay for his cost of living independently from an institution. He does not want to go into an institution; he prefers to stay in a home environment. Mr Sinibaldi is a quadriplegic. He has no use of his feet or legs and very little use of his arms and hands. He is immobile, other than through the use of an electronically controlled wheelchair. He relies totally on carers for his every requirement: feeding, bathing, getting into and out of bed, drinking, turning over. As I said, my constituent chooses to live alone. He values his independence. He likes to be at home; he does not want to be in an institution. But he recognises and accepts that he has care for about 18 out of 24 hours. He probably needs care for 24 hours, but he simply cannot afford it. There are two issues at stake which I want to develop. I simply ask the minister to have a look at these issues and perhaps at some later stage of this debate he might be able to come back to me. If he cannot come back to me today, I would accept that, but I would really appreciate the minister's views on the things that I am about to outline. The first issue is whether Mr Sinibaldi should be entitled to a tax deduction for his cost of employing carers, or whether he should only receive the current available rebate, which is 20 cents in the dollar over and above expenditure of about $1,250 a year-I am not certain of that figure. The other issue is that the cost of providing amenities for carers is currently subject to neither a rebate nor an allowable tax deduction. I simply ask that the minister have a look at these issues and perhaps he might be able to take them on board. But in developing the argument about the first issue, which is that carers' wages should be tax deductible, I will just say this: Mr Sinibaldi's funds are carefully invested, so as to produce sufficient income to meet his expenses, and these expenses are quite considerable. His carers' wages are $75,000 per annum. Costs for carers' amenities are in the vicinity of $2,340 per annum. His personal living costs are about $20,000 per annum. That amounts of $97,340 per annum. The generation of this income means that my constituent is liable to pay tax at the top marginal rate of 49.6 per cent, which is inclusive of the Medicare levy on nearly $50,000 of his income. The income generated goes, in the main, to pay his carers. He pays tax on that income and, in turn, the carers pay tax on their earnings. As I understand it, he is entitled to claim a rebate of 20c against his medical costs. That only partly defrays the 49.6 per cent income tax liability on the bulk of his income. He is left with a situation where he has a tax liability of about $35,000 each year. He has that liability because he is a quadriplegic who requires care. As I said, he has to generate a lot of income to cover those costs-something like $130,000 per annum before he 4128 MAIN COMMIITEE Tuesday, 23 March 1999 pays tax and the other carers' costs about which I spoke. Of course, he also needs to generate the amount of about $20,000 needed for his personal living expenses. I might say that while he is outside of an institution and in a home he lives quite frugally. I have actually visited him in his home and he looks after his dollars; he simply has to. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, would probably understand how difficult it is in today's economic environment to generate that sort of an income. Going back to the rebate, it seems that the rebate was conceived as being a fair method of compensating people for medical costs without encouraging unnecessary spending. It was probably also implemented without thought for people in my particular constituent's situation, but with bracket creep affecting tax on earnings and with the continually rising cost of living, clearly the rebate does not fairly compensate people with higher incomes required to meet medical expenses. As my constituent was awarded his lump sum to enable him to live independently, it seems only fair that he be given an opportunity to use his funds for that purpose rather than seeing those funds largely being absorbed in taxes. He is currently eating into his capital, Mr Deputy Speaker, and it seems that in the foreseeable future he is going to find it harder to generate the sort of income that he requires to live independently and to pay his carers. What is going to happen is that he is going to find himself, if he is not cautious, back in an institution or relying on some other public monies to enable him to ha"e the sort of care that he wants. That is why I am saying that parts 2, 3 and 4 of schedule 1, which make these minor technical amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Acts do not really go far enough. That is why I want to take this opportunity during this debate to get the minister to perhaps have a look at the issues that I am raising. We all know that five minutes prevention can often negate a whole lot of problems further down the track. In relation to my constituent, carers come in for 18 of the 24 hours per day, and two carers are in the house for four hours in the morning. As I said, he would really like to have care for 24 hours but it is just not something he can afford. The cost of running his home is largely related to the cost of his carers. More than half of all household items consumed and depreciated would relate to use and wear and tear by carers for their own reasonable amenity. The expenses attached to the day-to-day requirements of the carers are simply an extension of his medical carer costs. While this is only $2,340 per annum, the income that must be generated to pay these costs attracts the top marginal tax rate, as I have explained. As these expenses are purely the result of his need for care, perhaps this item should also be subject to either the medical rebate or treated as a tax deductible item because without carers the costs would not be incurred. I will give you an itemisation of these costs as they were presented to me. Carers sleep in the house overnight, every night, which means that a room must be kept solely for the use of carers. Each carer requires freshly laundered bed linen, evening tea and coffee, a morning meal and a morning shower. Expenses relating to the provision of these facilities for carers are: laundry goods; wear and tear on the washing machine; power; tea, coffee, toast, cereals and fruit et cetera; and cooking utensils and the power that they consume. He goes on to tell me that there needs to be the replacement of linen every nine to 12 months, for example, three sets of sheets and pillowcases. Doona covers, mattress protectors and other bedroom items require replacement less often. The bed and mattress depreciate and require replacement probably on a 10-year or so rotation. Toiletries and cleaning goods such Tuesday, 23 March 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 4129 as soap, toilet paper and general maintenance, including light bulbs, also need to be taken into account for the 12 hours that the overnight carers work. . Generally, the things I have listed here are the things that, as we go about our general dayto-day living as able-bodied persons, we would consume and use ourselves. But, as I have said, because this bloke requires carers-not just one carer, but a number of carers over the course of the day-the use of these things is much more pronounced. The use is probably similar to that of a family with three or four kids rather than an individual, as this person is, living in a home and trying to stay independent, trying to stay away from the government purse, and trying to stay out of an institution. He goes on to tell me that he estimates that a sum of about $5 per day would cover consumables, and the depreciation of furniture could either be calculated on a straight line basis over 10 years, or that a flat sum of $10 per week could be allowed for wear and tear and replacement. In total, he believes that the cost would realistically be $5 by seven days, plus $10 per week, which equals $45 per week, or $2,340 per annum, which I mentioned as the figure he has come up with. Having visited Mr Sinibaldi I know that he lives conservatively, and he keeps costs down as a matter of necessity. He needs to do this to ensure that he is not running over his budget, and to ensure that the dollars he is generating as a result of his investments are there to pay for the type of care that he requires. As I said, as conservative as he is, it is very difficult to foresee his future and to foresee where his investments might be and what they will be generating two or three years down the track. I apologise if I have strayed a little bit further than the bill would normally have taken me, but I think it is important when we talk about carers to look at both sides of the coin. HereI have given you a situation where the government has brought forward a bill which the opposition has said it supports. We have voiced reservations to that support, but in giving that support, as I am today speaking on the Hll, I also wanted to draw to the attention of the minister and of the committee, this other side of the coin so that we can see that there is still a lot of work required. I do not want to get into a debate about the GST, and perhaps some will argue that this bloke will get some relief under a GST given the income that he is generating, but we do not know what impact he will suffer as a result of the GST and perhaps that is something that the minister could have a look at. I will conclude my remarks fairly soon, but I did want to reiterate that which I said at the start of my comments on this bill. None of us in this place should lose sight of the need for those who are in receipt of care to have that care delivered in a dignified way, and neither should we lose sight of the need for those who provide the care to be able to do it in a dignified way. Giving care, either on a professional basis, or on a basis where you are looking after someone who is a family member, where you are not being paid, requires a great degree of commitment. I have great respect for people in that situation where they have to give care, and I think that we in this place, regardless of which side we sit on, should do all in our power to ensure that that dignity is there as much as it possibly can be. Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (6.17 p.m.)-I sympathise wholeheartedly with the previous speaker, the member for Cowan, and his story about his constituent and the care that is required around the clock. It is a very intensive process and he made a great and painstaking effort today to go through the daily costs of a person who is at home, who has a disability
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: And Requires Constant Care. People Like Mr Sinibaldi
theText: and I hope I have said that correctly4130 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 23 Mar.ch 1999 have the choice to stay at home because of a number of aspects that this· government has brought in that were not there before. It is always preferable to stay in one's home and be in the comfort and the familiar surrounding of one's home. People like that constituent would not have been able to stay at home had we not brought in a vast array of measures in the particular area that we are all speaking on today. I sympathise with the member for Cowan. I know the problems of carirtg for elderly relatives. I meet regularly with people in the community who have to care for people with disabilities, and the enormous strain that imposes on their daily lives and their family lives is very apparent to all of us in this room. I know that there is a great deal more that can be done and I would not hesitate to recommend that more be done in this area for people. But it needs to be brought to the attention of member for Cowan that this government has achieved a great deal, and I would like to reiterate some of those things that we have done. When the Howard government came into office in 1996 we inherited a system and an economy on the edge of collapse. In that time we have managed through our economic policies to reshape some of those mismanaged and misguided policies of those Hawke-Keating Labor years. The previous Labor government was driving the economy into the ground. They ignored so many areas because of their rather arrogant and indifferent attitude towards the plight of the people that we are speaking about today, battling Australians. The Assistance for Carers Legislation Amendment Bill 1999, unlike so many that have come here before under Labor, will address the needs of an average group of Australians who provide the community with an incredibly valuable service. The fine work that they do must be reiterated-and at little or no cost in the past. The Assistance for Carers Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 recognises the demanding work and the hardship that comes with being a carer. It is a 24-hour job and a very relentless one at that. But the carers that I speak to do it with great compassion and great love. It is a bill that redresses the balance in an area that was neglected by the previous· Labor government. The provisions in this bill deliver on the government's April 1998 Staying at Home package. That was quite a revolutionary package, which made life a lot easier for hundreds of thousands of Australians. These measures that we are speaking about here today will go a long way towards making life much easier for carers. The principal reform of the bill is the introduction of a new social security payment, the carer allowance. This carer allowance will combine two existing payments: the child disability allowance payment and the domiciliary nursing care benefit. It actually makes it a more simple system. The child disability allowance formerly provided a benefit to the carers of children up to the age of 16. Conversely, the domiciliary nursing care benefit was paid to carers of people aged 16 or more. In this bill, the carer allowance will bring the two together. The combination of these two payments will also be complemented by a liberalisation of the eligibility criteriafoi: the new carer allowance. The current eligibility criteria do not really allow for sufficient flexibility in the recognition of the role of carers of adult sufferers. For example, as it stands at the moment, access to domiciliary nursing care benefit is based on whether or not the carer requires ongoing nursing care and also on whether or not the person would be eligible for nursing home car-. This poses a real problem for many carers of people of adult age in that it locks them really out of the benefit because of the rigid definition of the role of a carer. Tuesday, 23 March 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 4131 The criteria also fail to recognise and include people who care for people who need high level care; The previous speaker mentioned a person in that particular position, a high level care person who needs constant supervision but does not need continuous nursing care. Carers of dementia sufferers and of people with multiple disabilities are therefore ineligible. The Howard government believes that these carers should be eligible for assistance and that is why this bill introduces a new assessment method for the carer allowance for the adult stream, and I would like to commend that recognition. Schedule 1, part 1 of the bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 to create the adult disabilityass.essment tool. The new assessment tool will ease the eligibility criteria for the carer allowance by more broadly recognising the needs of carers and the recipients .of care. This is a very progressive move that the government anticipates will see some 14,000 carers take up assistance for the first time. I know the carers in the Petrie electorate will be very pleased to see this in place. From July 1999, the government will inject approximately $98.5 million over four years into the carer allowance and this is a huge step forward. Liberalising the eligibility criteria is also an important step. Exempting the carer allowance from means and income tests reflects the government's commitment to Australian carers. We will always have an ongoing commitment to people in this particular role. The liberalisation of the eligibility criteria for the carer allowance will also extend to the means tested pension payment for carers, and that is the carer payment. The introduction of the adult disability assessment tool covering carers who look after adults with disabilities where the disabled adult has a child under six or children under 16 with qualifying disabilities is a welcome measure. In my role as a federal member I quite often have to attend functions that are put on in my electorate and I admire people like those in the Endeavour Foundation and the work that they do with people with disabilities. It is important to note that there is a need for more services like that in the community. What is more, this bill also makes provision for carer payment recipients to receive a bereavement payment on the death of a partner who was in receipt of a social security benefit. That can be a very welcome thing. It is a very distressing time when a partner is lost in these circumstances. I do work in my electorate for Meals on Wheels and I was quite pleased one day to be able to assist someone who was placed in this position. The impact that the death of a person has on the partner's life can never be underestimated. The elderly gentleman in question was very distressed and was not even able to pick up the phone and make a phone call to Social Security. We must always recognise that a lot of people in that situation do not have any family or any people that they can call on. The bill makes provision for a bereavement payment. That is a very welcome addition. The bill also provides for the recipients of both the carer allowance and payment to claim benefits while the care recipient is in hospital for a period of up to 63 days in a calendar year. I believe. that this isa very welcome measure as well. Carers have spoken to me about this in particular. Carers, as 1 am sure many people would agree, playa very important role in our community. It is not a role that people seek out by choice; it is a role that they are often driven to by tragic circumstances. They are often looking after elderly parents. I think back to when I was in my teens and my mother cared for our grandfather at home. It gave me a new insight into the constant care that she provided-I think that, as younger teenagers, we often underestimated 4132 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 23 March 1999 the care that she provided in our home. Having worked with people in this situation and spoken to many carers, I think it is something that we should never underestimate. In Australia today, nearly half of all people with dementia live at home, and I would like to speak about that. They are also dependent on carers for support. Without that particular support, dementia sufferers would be institutionalised. Dementia is often caused by a variety of reasons, a lot of which are medical reasons. I think we need to provide for those people and ensure that they are in a safe and comfortable environment, and quite often the home is that environment. In recognition of the contribution carers make to the community, the Howard government has also increased funding available for carers, despite the budgetary constraints imposed upon the government's social program by Labor's mismanagement. That needs to be highlighted here. Despite the fiscal difficulties that Labor brought upon the current administration, the government has been able to set aside $280 million as part of a staying at home package. In summary, I would like to reiterate my pride in being a member of the Howard government that has put this bill in place. I also believe that any measures that can somehow lighten the heavy burden that is carried by carers are worthy of unequivocal support. I commend this bill to the House.
